tidypandas.series_utils._extend(aseries, length)[source]#

_extend Extends a series to a given length by repeating the values of the series

Parameters

  • aseries (A pandas series) –

  • length (int) – length to repeat to

Return type

A pandas series

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([1,2,3])
>>> _extend(ser, 5)
tidypandas.series_utils.ifelse(condition, yes, no)[source]#

ifelse Vectorized if and else

Parameters

  • condition (expression or list/array/Series) – Should evaluate to a boolean list/array/Series

  • yes (expression or list/array/Series) – Should evaluate to a list/array/Series

  • no (expression or list/array/Series) – Should evaluate to a list/array/Series

Return type

Pandas Series

Notes

  1. Thin wrapper over np.where

  2. Does not preserve index.

Examples

>>> x = pd.Series([1,pd.NA,3]).astype('Int64')
>>> y = pd.Series([4,5,6]).astype('Int64')
>>> z = pd.Series([7,8,9]).astype('Int64')
>>>
>>> ifelse(x > 2, y + 1, z - 1)
tidypandas.series_utils.if_else#
tidypandas.series_utils.coalesce(list_of_series)[source]#

coalesce Given a list of pandas Series, coalesce finds the first non-missing value at each position for the first Series in the list

Parameters

list_of_series (list) – List of pandas Series

Return type

Pandas Series of length of the first series in the input list

Notes

  1. If on the inputs has length 1, then it is extended. Else, inputs are expected to have same length.

  1. Does not preserve index.

Examples

>>> x = pd.Series([1, pd.NA, pd.NA])
>>> y = pd.Series([4, 5    , pd.NA])
>>> z = pd.Series([7, 8    , pd.NA])
>>> a = 10
>>>
>>> coalesce([x, y, z, a])
tidypandas.series_utils.case_when(list_of_tuples, default=pd.NA)[source]#

case_when Vectorized version of multiple ifelse statements

Parameters

  • list_of_tuples (list) – First element of the tuple should be an expression when evaluated should result in a boolean array/Series. Second element of the tuple should be the value to be assigned to the postitions corresponding the boolean array/Series

  • default (scalar value to assign when none of the conditions are met.) – Default is pd.NA.

Return type

Pandas Series

Notes

  1. Does not preserve index.

Examples

>>> x = pd.Series([3, 5 , pd.NA, 4]).astype('Int64')
>>>
>>> case_when([(x >= 5, 500), (x >= 4, 400), (pd.isna(x), 1)])
>>> case_when([(x >= 5, 500), (x >= 4, 400)], default = 100)
tidypandas.series_utils.n_distinct(x, na_rm=False)[source]#

n_distinct Number of distinct values in a series

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series) –

  • False) (na_rm (default is) –

Return type

int, Number of distinct values

tidypandas.series_utils._order_series(x, na_position='last')[source]#

_order_series Permutation order of the series

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series) –

  • na_position (str, One among "first", "last") –

Return type

A pandas series indicating the permutation order

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([3, 1, 2, pd.NA]).astype('Int64')
>>> _order_series(ser)
tidypandas.series_utils.order(x, ascending=True, na_position='last')[source]#

order Permutation order of the series or a list of series

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series or a list of series) –

  • ascending (str or a list of bools) – When a list, should have match the length of x

  • na_position (str) – One among: “first”, “last”

Notes

1. When x is a list of series, 2nd series is used to beak the ties in the 1st series and so on.

Return type

A pandas series indicating the permutation order

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([3, 1, 2, pd.NA]).astype('Int64')
>>> order(ser)
>>>
>>> sers = [pd.Series([1, 1]).astype('Int64'), pd.Series([2, 1]).astype('Int64')]
>>> order(sers)
tidypandas.series_utils._rank(x, type, ascending=True, percent=False)[source]#

_rank ranking order of the series or a list of series

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series or a list of series) –

  • type (One among "min", "first", "dense", "max") –

  • ascending (str or a list of bools) – When a list, should have match the length of x

  • percent (bool) – Should the ranking order be converted to percentages

Notes

1. When x is a list of series, 2nd series is used to beak the ties in the 1st series and so on.

Return type

A pandas series

Notes

Missing values are left as is. If you want to treat them as the smallest or largest values, replace with Inf or -Inf before ranking.

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([3, 1, 2, pd.NA]).astype('Int64')
>>> _rank(ser, "first")
>>>
>>> sers = [pd.Series([1, 1]).astype('Int64'), pd.Series([2, 1]).astype('Int64')]
>>> _rank(sers, "min")
tidypandas.series_utils.min_rank(x, ascending=True)[source]#

min_rank ranking order with ties set to minimum rank

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series or a list of series) –

  • ascending (str or a list of bools) – When a list, should have match the length of x

  • percent (bool) – Should the ranking order be converted to percentages

Notes

1. When x is a list of series, 2nd series is used to beak the ties in the 1st series and so on.

Returns

  • Missing values are left as is. If you want to treat them as the smallest

  • or largest values, replace with Inf or -Inf before ranking.

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([3, 1, 2, 1, 3, pd.NA, 2]).astype('Int64')
>>> min_rank(ser)
tidypandas.series_utils.row_number(x, ascending=True)[source]#

row_number ranking order with ties set to first rank

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series or a list of series) –

  • ascending (str or a list of bools) – When a list, should have match the length of x

  • percent (bool) – Should the ranking order be converted to percentages

Notes

1. When x is a list of series, 2nd series is used to beak the ties in the 1st series and so on.

Returns

  • Missing values are left as is. If you want to treat them as the smallest

  • or largest values, replace with Inf or -Inf before ranking.

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([3, 1, 2, 1, 3, pd.NA, 2]).astype('Int64')
>>> row_number(ser)
tidypandas.series_utils.dense_rank(x, ascending=True)[source]#

dense_rank ranking order with ties so that there is no gaps in ranks

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series or a list of series) –

  • ascending (str or a list of bools) – When a list, should have match the length of x

  • percent (bool) – Should the ranking order be converted to percentages

Notes

1. When x is a list of series, 2nd series is used to beak the ties in the 1st series and so on.

Returns

  • Missing values are left as is. If you want to treat them as the smallest

  • or largest values, replace with Inf or -Inf before ranking.

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([4, 1, 2, 1, 3, pd.NA, 2]).astype('Int64')
>>> dense_rank(ser)
tidypandas.series_utils.percent_rank(x, ascending=True)[source]#

percent_rank ranking order witbh ties set to minimum rank rescaled between 0 and 1

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series or a list of series) –

  • ascending (str or a list of bools) – When a list, should have match the length of x

  • percent (bool) – Should the ranking order be converted to percentages

Notes

1. When x is a list of series, 2nd series is used to beak the ties in the 1st series and so on.

Returns

  • Missing values are left as is. If you want to treat them as the smallest

  • or largest values, replace with Inf or -Inf before ranking.

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([3, 1, 2, 1, 3, pd.NA, 2]).astype('Int64')
>>> percent_rank(ser)
tidypandas.series_utils.cume_dist(x, ascending=True)[source]#

cume_dist ranking order with ties set to maximum rank rescaled between 0 and 1

Parameters

  • x (A pandas series or a list of series) –

  • ascending (str or a list of bools) – When a list, should have match the length of x

  • percent (bool) – Should the ranking order be converted to percentages

Notes

1. When x is a list of series, 2nd series is used to beak the ties in the 1st series and so on.

Returns

  • Missing values are left as is. If you want to treat them as the smallest

  • or largest values, replace with Inf or -Inf before ranking.

Examples

>>> ser = pd.Series([3, 1, 2, 1, 3, pd.NA, 2]).astype('Int64')
>>> cume_dist(ser)
tidypandas.series_utils.as_bool(x)[source]#

as_bool Convert boolean or object dtype series to bool series with NAs as False Helpful in combining multiple series in ‘filter’

Parameters

x (pandas series) – Should have one of these dtypes: bool, boolean, object

Return type

A pandas series of dtype bool

Examples

ser = pd.Series([True, False, pd.NA]) print(str(ser.dtype))

print(as_bool(ser)) print(str(as_bool(ser).dtype))

ser2 = ser.convert_dtypes() print(str(ser2.dtype))

print(as_bool(ser2)) print(str(as_bool(ser2).dtype))
